title: Trying to create a multiboot usb, can't find the right way

forumNotes.author: pnikkosis
forumNotes.content:
Hi everyone, sorry if this sounds a bit newbie, but I'm trying to create a multiboot usb. I have a couple of ISOs i'd like to boot, mainly it's an AIO Win7 iso, gparted and backtrack5. (sometimes I use ophcrack or hirens, but that can be discarded).  
I have tried xboot, yumi, sardu; but there seems to be more to it than just selecting the ISOs.  
Can anyone give me a hand? I have problems already in something simple as gparted not booting (and it's supported by all this programs). I formatted to FAT32 before trying every program, but still no luck. I used the microsoft tool to make a usb stick with a win7 install iso, and I have another one with gpard working, but the idea is carrying just one stick, not one for every iso.  
Can this 3 things be in one same usb stick?   

**Edited by pnikkosis, 30 October 2012 - 10:02 PM.**

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Yes. Grub4dos can do these 3 and more. See tutorials on my site. You can even have Vista 32\&64, Win7 32\&64, Server 2008R2 and Win8 installs on same USB boot drive, + ophcrack + hirens + BT5 + gparted + many linux OS's + UBCD + many more - all on same USB drive. Just follow each tutorial and add to the menu.lst file.  

Gparted - Tutorial 14  
BT5 - Tutorial 9  
Win7 Install ISO - Tutorial 43  
Hirens - Tutorial 36  
Ophcrack - Tutorial 13

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
If grub4dos is installed then the bootloader option is irrelevant (any choice will do). If you are making a multiboot drive, I would suggest you use FAT32 as some linux distros and DOS cannot read NTFS. You will however have the 4GB max file size limit.  
Tut 14 has gparted in it - example menus for pure gparted can be found in the grub4dos tutorial #21 Examples section.
